items.title: SNOW-183856: Snowflake missing out on all that free testing from it's users
items.body:
This is come up a bunch of times in the issues about aggressive version pinning from this package. I understand that you have a solid testing infrastructure so you can verify things work with other things, however, version pinning is a downstream concern from the package maintainer unless there is a known incompatibility or bug, additionally I don't believe that your testing infrastructure covers all the use cases that your users are striving to implement. You have all these talented uses testing your software on version combinations and implementation scenarios you could never cover.

Additionally - bugs in dependencies become your bugs because you locked yourself into them without allowing users to upgrade themselves out of an issue - that would require extra handling of bugs which are just not relevant to snowflake-connector python. For example, even at a discussion level, in some of the threads it is there is mention of interactions between boto3 and requests, but why is that even a discussion? There is no bug in snowflake-connector-python, and energy is wasted discussing and pain in inherited by the users of snowflake-connector-python for needing to deal with the issue at a level that it needed to be dealt with.

I would suggest that documenting a known good version set from your testing would be very helpful and appreciated or documenting frequently encountered problems that may occur in implementing the package would be the simplest approach.

Additionally additionally - it is a wast of time to debug issues or submit bugs reports on old versions of software. If one encounter a bug in boto3 or requests (more likely boto3) then the first action should be to upgrade it - nobody appreciates bug reports for bugs they have fixed already.

items.title: SNOW-179577: Issue while using pd_writer: **MissingDependencyError: Missing optional dependency: pandas**
items.body:
Python version -- 3.7.3
pyarrow -- 0.17.1 
snowflake-connector-python -- 2.2.8     
Operating system and processor architecture: Windows-10-10.0.17763-SP0

I'm trying to write a dataframe to snowflakes using pd_writer
So to import i used the below code:  
**from snowflake.connector.pandas_tools import pd_writer** 

I got the error:
**MissingDependencyError: Missing optional dependency: pandas**

To reproduce the error, call the `fetch_pandas_all()` function, like so:

```python
def execute_query(query_string):
    cursor = snowflake.connector.connect(…).cursor()
    try:
        cursor.execute(query_string)
        result = cursor.fetch_pandas_all()
    finally:
        cursor.close()
    return result

query_string = 'select a.col1, a.col2 from my_database.my_schema.my_table as t limit 100;'

data = execute_query(query_string)
```

That will result in this pyarrow-related error:

```
Exception has occurred: ProgrammingError
255002: pyarrow package is missing. Install using pip if the platform is supported.
```

I would expect the `snowflake-connector-python` package to install its own dependencies as needed.

Note that using the `fetchall()` function works fine:

```python
def execute_query(query_string):
    cursor = get_connection().cursor()
    try:
        cursor.execute(query_string)
        result = cursor.fetchall()
    finally:
        cursor.close()
    return result
```

The issue seems to be related to converting the SQL query result to a Pandas dataframe.

items.title: SNOW-172208: AttributeError: 'SSLSocket' object has no attribute 'connection' while running test on Airflow
items.body:

`Python 3.7.8`

```python
import logging

)

]


def row_count(**context):
    dwh_hook = SnowflakeHook(snowflake_conn_id="snowflake")

with dag:
```

4. What did you do?
OK, here is the Snowflake docs how to bring a pandas DataFrame to Snowflke: 
[https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/python-connector-api.html#label-python-connector-api-write-pandas](url)

I'm trying to follow exact instructions. My dataframe is here:

`df_t = pd.DataFrame([(1.9204, 0, 1, 46.7300, 0, 113000, 113000, '2012-03-10 13:09:06.290',
                     '2012-03-10 13:09:06.290',  50192, 'A', 'Y', 'N', 'N', 'NNN', 2, 0, 1,
                     '2012-03-10 19:50:58.233', '2012-03-10 19:50:59.800', '2020-02-27 15:10:07.457',
                     '2020-02-27 15:10:07.457',168)], columns = cols)`
Actually, I'm trying to bring data from SQL Server->DataFrame->Snowflake. Please, don't tell me about csv files. I did it already. :-)
Anyway, after using this, according to docs, I execute a function:

`success, nchunks, nrows, _ = write_pandas(conn, df_t, 'Some_Table')`

And I get this error:

`snowflake.connector.errors.ProgrammingError: 001003 (42000): SQL compilation error:
 syntax error line 1 at position 87 unexpected '~'.

 parse error line 1 at position 104 near '84'.

4. What did you do?

There are many cases where the `location` (https://github.com/snowflakedb/snowflake-connector-python/blob/master/pandas_tools.py#L87) is not constructed correctly in `write_pandas`. Take three examples that are all possible and incorrect:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3588399/85385658-de48bf80-b542-11ea-82d6-e537da53442d.png)

The result is that the user always need to do something like 

```
conn.execute(f"use database {db}")
conn.execute(f"create schema if not exists {schema}")
conn.execute(f"use schema {schema}")
conn.execute(f"create table if not exists {table}")
```

to use `pd_writer` / `write_pandas`.

items.title: SNOW-168810: Creating .whl files in windows
items.body:
Please answer these questions before submitting your issue. Thanks!

1. What version of Python are you using (`python --version`)? V3

2. What operating system and processor architecture are you using (`python -c 'import platform; print(platform.platform())'`)? Windows

Where to find the snowflake_connector_python*.whl files in windows ?
attached is the response after calling setup.py command

[access whl files in windows.txt](https://github.com/snowflakedb/snowflake-connector-python/files/4792892/access.whl.files.in.windows.txt)

items.title: SNOW-165822: fetch_pandas_batches batch size
items.body: Is there a way to control the batch size for the `fetch_pandas_batches` method?

items.title: SNOW-165626: Support cffi v1.14.0
items.body:
Hello,

Would there be any issue supporting cffi v1.14.0?

Currently we are restricted to versions between 1.9 and less than 1.14:
```
'cffi>=1.9,<1.14',
```
https://github.com/snowflakedb/snowflake-connector-python/blob/v2.25/setup.py#L188

items.title: SNOW-163889: Support azure-storage-blob v12 api
items.body:
I have a project using `python 3.8.2` with code written against `azure-storage-blob 12.3.1`

The problem is `snowflake-connector-python 2.2.6` has requirement `azure-storage-blob<12.0.0`.

I'm not keen re-writing my code for the older azure azure-storage-blob sdk which is quite different. Please keep this library up to date with the latest version of dependencies or internalize them somehow.

items.title: SNOW-162284: Documentation question for write_pandas
items.body:
More of a question with regards to the docs here: https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/python-connector-api.html#write_pandas

It specifically says: `and uses the COPY INTO <location> ` Should this be `and uses the COPY INTO <table> `? Looking at the code the variable is called `location` but it should be `COPY INTO <table>` in theory?

 Thanks for the hard work on the connector :)

items.title: SNOW-159405: snowflake-connector-python 2.2.4 requires keyring in setup.py
items.body:
Please answer these questions before submitting your issue. Thanks!

1. What version of Python are you using (`python --version`)?
3.7.7

typical log messages

```
  File "/Users/shh/Development/turtle-feeder/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/snowflake/connector/connection.py", line 189, in __init__

  File "/Users/shh/Development/turtle-feeder/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/snowflake/connector/connection.py", line 493, in connect
```

Once I ran `pip install keyring` everything worked. I believe this means there is a missing dep in setup.py .

items.title: SNOW-152226: snowflake.connector.errors.OperationalError: 250003: Failed to execute request: 'APIException' object has no attribute 'errno'
items.body:
Hi,

I'm getting an error that I can't seem to resolve.
Does anyone have a solution?

-------------------------------------------------
Please answer these questions before submitting your issue. Thanks!

1. What version of Python are you using (`python --version`)?
Python 3.7.6 :: Anaconda, Inc. on win32

2. What operating system and processor architecture are you using (`python -c 'import platform; print(platform.platform())'`)?
Windows-10-10.0.17763-SP0

3. What are the component versions in the environment (`pip list`)? 
snowflake-connector-python         2.0.0
snowflake-sqlalchemy               1.2.3

4. What did you do?
If possible, provide a recipe for reproducing the error.
A complete runnable program is good.
-------------
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import sys
import snowflake.connector

def runSQL(sql, dumpsql=True):

	print("-- SQL Start --")

	ctx = snowflake.connector.connect(
		user='***',
		password='***',
		account='***',
		authenticator='***'
	)
	cs = ctx.cursor()
	df = None
	try:
		sqlList = sql.split(";")
		for row in sqlList:
			row = row.strip()
			if (len(row) > 0):
				if (dumpsql):
					print(row)
				test = cs.execute(row)
				if (dumpsql):
					print("done")
				if (cs.description is not None):
					rows = cs.fetchall()
					df = pd.DataFrame(np.array(rows));
					if (len(df) > 0):
						df.columns = pd.DataFrame(np.matrix(cs.description))[0]
					else:
						df = pd.DataFrame(columns=pd.DataFrame(np.matrix(cs.description))[0])

		print("-- Success --")

	finally:
		cs.close()

	ctx.close()
	return df
----------------
5. What did you expect to see?
To be authenticated / print "-- Success --".

6. What did you see instead?
snowflake.connector.errors.OperationalError: 250003: Failed to execute request: 'APIException' object has no attribute 'errno'

7. Can you set logging to DEBUG and collect the logs?
No.

4. What did you do?
from azure.storage.blob import BlobServiceClient

uploading files to Azure blob Container requires 'BlobServiceClient' from azure.storage.blob
this is missing from azure.storage.blob provided from snowflake-connector-python
so I installed azure-storage-blob==12.0.0 (this is only compatible version with snowflake)

this messed up 'BlockBlobService' from 'azure.storage.blob', of snowflake-connector-python
now my python scripts are not working, upgrading snowflake-connector-python gave this error.

ERROR: snowflake-connector-python 2.2.2 has requirement azure-storage-blob<12.0.0, but you'll have azure-storage-blob 12.0.0 which is incompatible.

5. What did you expect to see?
azure-storage-blob supporting both BlobServiceClient and BlockBlobService

6. What did you see instead?
ERROR: snowflake-connector-python 2.2.2 has requirement azure-storage-blob<12.0.0, but you'll have azure-storage-blob 12.0.0 which is incompatible.

items.title: SNOW-146730: Support pandas 1.0

items.title: SNOW-139744: restrictive dependencies breaking projects
items.body:
Problem with python3.6 and python3.7 running on debian like and centos7 

Your setup.py has this definition limiting the versions of some mainstream packages like requests and idna:

    install_requires=[
...
        'requests<2.23.0',
        'idna<2.9'
...

It makes really hard to depend upon snowflake-connector-python since it's going to break any deployment as soon as you start using other library that also uses requests or idna ( this is very frequent in the python universe nowadays )

As it stands, this package installs boto3 (thereby including a bunch including botocore, s3transfer, etc) and azure-{common, storage-blob, storage-common}. For those on AWS, we don't need the Azure stuff, vice versa for those on Azure. For those working locally or not in a cloud, they get double-unwanted things! I would like to be able to `$ pip install snowflake-connector-python[aws]==X.Y.Z` and specify a specific version w/ only AWS packages in our requirements.txt as well. 6. What did you see instead? All cloud-specific packages get installed, no matter what. 7. Can you set logging to DEBUG and collect the logs? (this is not worth logging)

items.title: uppercaseing authenticator breaks Okta URL which may include case-sensitive elements
items.body:
Please answer these questions before submitting your issue. Thanks!

1. What version of Python are you using (`python --version`)?

3.8.1

2. What operating system and processor architecture are you using (`python -c 'import platform; print(platform.platform())'`)?

Linux-5.4.8-arch1-1-x86_64-with-glibc2.2.5

3. What are the component versions in the environment (`pip list`)? 

Package                    Version   
-------------------------- ----------
asn1crypto                 1.3.0     
attrs                      19.3.0    
azure-common               1.1.24    
azure-storage-blob         2.1.0     
azure-storage-common       2.1.0

oscrypto                   1.1.1     
packaging                  20.0      
pip                        19.3.1    
pluggy                     0.13.1    
py                         1.8.1     
pycparser                  2.19      
pycryptodomex              3.9.4     
PyJWT                      1.7.1     
pyOpenSSL                  19.1.0    
pyparsing                  2.4.6     
pytest                     5.3.2     
python-dateutil            2.8.1     
pytz                       2019.3    
requests                   2.22.0    
s3transfer                 0.2.1     
setuptools                 41.2.0    
six                        1.13.0    
snowflake-connector-python 2.1.3     
urllib3                    1.25.7    
wcwidth                    0.1.8     
wheel                      0.33.6    

4. What did you do?

`connection.py` uppercases the authenticator option in line 765. In case of the Okta authenticator, the authenticator parameter value is the Okta URL. Sometimes, the URL may include case-sensitive elements (even though URLs are supposed to be generally case-insensitive, this is real life). For example, something like `https://someaccount.okta.com/snowflake/oO56fExYCGnfV83/2345`. Such URLs commonly appear when multiple applications are managed by Okta for a business account. Uppercasing the URL breaks the authentication. The bug affects `snowsql` tool as well since it uses the Python connector internally.

5. What did you expect to see?

If the authenticator parameter is an Okta URL, it should not be uppercase (or changed in any other way).

6. What did you see instead?

The URL is uppercased, which breaks it.

items.title: SQL Compilation Error on UPDATE
items.body:
I have an error on a simple update if I update more than one field. If I update only one field, no problems. Code to reproduce and the error is below:

version: snowflake-connector-python-2.1.2

 
```
#!/usr/bin/env python

""" test script to be sure connection with snowflake worked """
import json

import snowflake.connector

snowflake.connector.paramstyle = 'qmark'  # prepared statement use `?`
credentials = {
    'user': 'my_user',
    'password': 'my_password',
    'account': 'my_account',
    'warehouse': 'my_warehouse',
    'database': 'my_db',
}

ctx = snowflake.connector.connect(**credentials)
cs = ctx.cursor(snowflake.connector.DictCursor)
try:
    cs.execute("UPDATE objective_source SET objective_id = 3, source_type_id = 3 WHERE id = 3 ")
finally:
    cs.close()
ctx.close()

```

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
```

from snowflake.sqlalchemy import URL

        user='',

    print(results[0])
    con.close()
    engine.dispose()
    return results[0]


if __name__ == "__main__":
    lambda_handler(None,None)

items.title: Error with Python 3 only using version 2.0.4 : snowflake.connector.errors.OperationalError: 250003: Failed to execute request: 'SSLSocket' object has no attribute 'connection'
items.body:
Hi,

I would like to report an issue I have been experiencing with version 2.0.4 : When trying to run the snippet 'validate.py' showcased in the documentation I get a weird `snowflake.connector.errors.OperationalError: 250003: Failed to execute request: 'SSLSocket' object has no attribute 'connection'` for Python 3.5.2. For Python 2.7.12 the script run smoothly though.

With version 2.0.2 I was not getting that error either for Python 2.7.12 or Python 3.5.2. With version 2.0.3 I was getting this already reported issue : https://github.com/snowflakedb/snowflake-connector-python/issues/226

Many thanks in advance!

Please answer these questions before submitting your issue. Thanks!

1. What version of Python are you using (`python --version`)?
`python3 --version
Python 3.5.2
`
2. What operating system and processor architecture are you using (`python -c 'import platform; print(platform.platform())'`)?
`python -c 'import platform; print(platform.platform())'
Linux-4.8.0-53-generic-x86_64-with-LinuxMint-18.2-sonya`
3. What are the component versions in the environment (`pip list`)? 
`asn1crypto                 1.2.0                 
azure-common               1.1.23                
azure-storage-blob         2.1.0                 
azure-storage-common       2.1.0                 
boto3                      1.9.253               
botocore                   1.12.253              
certifi                    2019.9.11             
cffi                       1.13.2                
cryptography               2.8                   
idna                       2.0                   
ijson                      2.5.1                              
oscrypto                   1.1.0                 
pip                        19.3.1                
pycrypto                   2.6.1                 
pycryptodomex              3.9.3                 
pycurl                     7.43.0                           
PyJWT                      1.3.0                 
pyOpenSSL                  19.0.0                  
pytz                       2019.3                
requests                   2.9.1                               
six                        1.10.0                
snowflake-connector-python 2.0.4                 
urllib3                    1.24.3 `               
4. What did you do?
If possible, provide a recipe for reproducing the error.
A complete runnable program is good.
ran the validate.py snippet from the documentation : https://docs.snowflake.net/manuals/user-guide/python-connector-install.html
5. What did you expect to see?
I did not expect to see any errors
6. What did you see instead?
`snowflake.connector.errors.OperationalError: 250003: Failed to execute request: 'SSLSocket' object has no attribute 'connection'
`
7. Can you set logging to DEBUG and collect the logs?

```
import logging
import os

for logger_name in ['snowflake.sqlalchemy', 'snowflake.connector', 'botocore']: 
    logger = logging.getLogger(logger_name)
    logger.setLevel(logging.DEBUG)

    logger.addHandler(ch)
```

items.title: Pass down ssl_context to `urllib3.util.ssl_wrap_socket`
items.body:
Hi,

Thanks for your work on the snowflake connector! 

I have an issue with SSL handshake that I'll try to describe below.

1. What version of Python are you using (`python --version`)?

`3.6.8`

2. What operating system and processor architecture are you using (`python -c 'import platform; print(platform.platform())'`)?

`Linux-4.16.0-1-amd64-x86_64-with-debian-bullseye-sid`

3. What are the component versions in the environment (`pip list`)? 

```$ pip list | grep -i -E 'ssl|urllib|cert|snow'                                                                                         11:18:09
certifi                    2019.9.11 
pyOpenSSL                  19.1.0    
snowflake-connector-python 2.0.4     
urllib3                    1.24.3    
```

4. What did you do?

```python
import urllib3
import snowflake.connector  # ← comment this line and everything is fine


def get(url):
    pool_manager = urllib3.PoolManager()
    res = pool_manager.request('GET', url)
    return res.status


assert get('https://wikipedia.org') == 200
```

5. What did you expect to see?

I expect not to see any error.

6. What did you see instead?

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/adim/debug-run/snowrror.py", line 11, in <module>
    assert get('https://wikipedia.org') == 200
  File "/home/adim/debug-run/snowrror.py", line 7, in get
    res = pool_manager.request('GET', url)
  File "/home/adim/.virtualenvs/peakina/lib/python3.6/site-packages/urllib3/request.py", line 68, in request
    **urlopen_kw)
  File "/home/adim/.virtualenvs/peakina/lib/python3.6/site-packages/urllib3/request.py", line 89, in request_encode_url
    return self.urlopen(method, url, **extra_kw)
  File "/home/adim/.virtualenvs/peakina/lib/python3.6/site-packages/urllib3/poolmanager.py", line 324, in urlopen
    response = conn.urlopen(method, u.request_uri, **kw)
  File "/home/adim/.virtualenvs/peakina/lib/python3.6/site-packages/urllib3/connectionpool.py", line 667, in urlopen
    **response_kw)
  File "/home/adim/.virtualenvs/peakina/lib/python3.6/site-packages/urllib3/connectionpool.py", line 667, in urlopen
    **response_kw)
  File "/home/adim/.virtualenvs/peakina/lib/python3.6/site-packages/urllib3/connectionpool.py", line 667, in urlopen
    **response_kw)
  File "/home/adim/.virtualenvs/peakina/lib/python3.6/site-packages/urllib3/connectionpool.py", line 638, in urlopen
    _stacktrace=sys.exc_info()[2])
  File "/home/adim/.virtualenvs/peakina/lib/python3.6/site-packages/urllib3/util/retry.py", line 399, in increment
    raise MaxRetryError(_pool, url, error or ResponseError(cause))
urllib3.exceptions.MaxRetryError: HTTPSConnectionPool(host='wikipedia.org', port=443): Max retries exceeded with url: / (Caused by SSLError(SSLError("bad handshake: Error([('SSL routines', 'tls_process_server_certificate', 'certificate verify failed')],)",),))
```

As far as I can, tell, the problem lies in the monkeypatch of `ssl_wrap_socket` with `ssl_wrap_socket_with_ocsp`  (cf. https://github.com/snowflakedb/snowflake-connector-python/blob/master/ssl_wrap_socket.py#L374 ). `ssl_context` is not passed down to the original function which causes the error. 

The error doesn't occur if `urllib3.PoolManager` is instantiated with `cert_reqs='CERT_REQUIRED', ca_certs=certifi.where()`.

items.title: Set current schema in connection string containing special characters
items.body:
Please answer these questions before submitting your issue. Thanks!

1. What version of Python are you using (`python --version`)?
   Python 3.6.5 (default, Jun 17 2018, 12:13:06) 
   [GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Apple LLVM 9.1.0 (clang-902.0.39.2)]

2. What operating system and processor architecture are you using (`python -c 'import platform; print(platform.platform())'`)?
   Darwin-18.7.0-x86_64-i386-64bit

3. What are the component versions in the environment (`pip list`)? 
    I'm using snowflake-connector-python 2.0.4    

4. What did you do?
     I want to set the current database and schema in the connection string, but it is not picked up if it contains special characters. The specified objects exists and I'm able to set the current database and schema with the "USE SCHEMA ..." statement once the connection is established.
    I think it is due to a missing urllib.parse.unqoute call before sending the string to authenticate()
```
   engine = create_engine(URL(
      account = '...',
      user = '...',
      password = '...',
      database = 'a/b/c',
      schema = 'd/e',
  ))

  conn = engine.connect()
```
   
5. What did you expect to see?
  [res for res in conn.execute("select current_warehouse(), current_database(), current_schema();")]
   [('...', 'a/b/c', 'd/e')]

6. What did you see instead?
    [res for res in conn.execute("select current_warehouse(), current_database(), current_schema();")]
   [('...', None, None)]

7. Can you set logging to DEBUG and collect the logs?
   Logs indicate that the string is not unescaped before passing it to authenticate, but authenticate will perform another url encoding on the string

    2019-11-13 10:53:59,915 - MainThread auth.py:165 - authenticate() - DEBUG - account=...., user=......, database=a%2Fb%2Fc,

items.title: Crash on MacOS Catalina
items.body:
When using Snowflake connector and Boto3 together on MacOS Catalina, the process dies when making any Boto3 request.  The problem did not occur with Mojave.

Note that we can workaround the issue by disabling the monkey-patch done in `ssl_wrap_socket.inject_into_urllib3`:

```
import requests
f = requests.packages.urllib3.connection.ssl_wrap_socket
import snowflake.connector
requests.packages.urllib3.connection.ssl_wrap_socket = f

import boto3
s3 = boto3.client('s3')
s3.head_object(Bucket='some-bucket', Key='some-key')
```
Please answer these questions before submitting your issue. Thanks!

1. What version of Python are you using (`python --version`)?
**Python 3.7.5**

2. What operating system and processor architecture are you using (`python -c 'import platform; print(platform.platform())'`)?
**Darwin-19.0.0-x86_64-i386-64bit**

3. What are the component versions in the environment (`pip list`)? 
```

-------------------------- ---------

awscli                     1.16.280
azure-common               1.1.23
azure-storage-blob         2.1.0

snowflake-connector-python 2.0.4
urllib3                    1.24.3

```
4. What did you do?
If possible, provide a recipe for reproducing the error.
A complete runnable program is good.
```
import snowflake.connector, boto3
s3 = boto3.client('s3')
s3.head_object(Bucket='some-bucket', Key='some-key')

```

items.title: Snowflake Docs Inaccurate for 2.0
items.body:
Please answer these questions before submitting your issue. Thanks!

4. What did you do?
Looking at the [Snowflake documentation](https://docs.snowflake.net/manuals/user-guide/python-connector-example.html#connecting-using-the-default-authenticator), it still shows using the `snowflake.connector.connect` method instead of instantiating the `SnowflakeConnection` class.

5. What did you expect to see?
```
from snowflake.connector import SnowflakeConnection
con = SnowflakeConnection(
  user=USER,
  password=PASSWORD,
  account=ACCOUNT,
  warehouse=WAREHOUSE,
  database=DATABASE,
  schema=SCHEMA
)
```

items.title: Please lazy import your cloud providers
items.body: Most people are not going to use all your cloud connectors. Can you lazy import so that we don't have install everything when we know we won't need them.

4. What did you do?
```
engine = create_engine(os.getenv('AIRFLOW_CONN_SNOWFLAKE_URL'))
engine.connect()
```
5. What did you expect to see?
We should be able to connect.

6. What did you see instead?
The connector breaks when trying to connect because it's passing in a cert_reqs parameter to urllib3, but I believe urllib3 <1.25.0 does not support this parameter.

items.title: azure-storage-blob 12.0.0 breaks connector version 1.9.1
items.body:
Please answer these questions before submitting your issue. Thanks!

1. What version of Python are you using (`python --version`)?

Python 2.7.15rc1

2. What operating system and processor architecture are you using (`python -c 'import platform; print(platform.platform())'`)?

Linux-3.10.0-514.21.2.el7.x86_64-x86_64-with-centos-7.3.1611-Core

3. What are the component versions in the environment (`pip list`)? 

snowflake-connector-python==1.9.1
azure-common==1.1.23
azure-core==1.0.0
azure-nspkg==3.0.2
azure-storage-blob==12.0.0
azure-storage-nspkg==3.1.0

4. What did you do?

import snowflake.connector

5. What did you expect to see?

no error

6. What did you see instead?

```
line 6, in <module>
    import snowflake.connector
  File "/home/etlprod/venv/di-measurements/lib/python2.7/site-packages/snowflake/connector/__init__.py", line 21, in <module>
    from .connection import SnowflakeConnection
  File "/home/etlprod/venv/di-measurements/lib/python2.7/site-packages/snowflake/connector/connection.py", line 44, in <module>
    from .cursor import SnowflakeCursor, LOG_MAX_QUERY_LENGTH
  File "/home/etlprod/venv/di-measurements/lib/python2.7/site-packages/snowflake/connector/cursor.py", line 26, in <module>
    from .file_transfer_agent import (SnowflakeFileTransferAgent)
  File "/home/etlprod/venv/di-measurements/lib/python2.7/site-packages/snowflake/connector/file_transfer_agent.py", line 20, in <module>
    from .azure_util import SnowflakeAzureUtil
  File "/home/etlprod/venv/di-measurements/lib/python2.7/site-packages/snowflake/connector/azure_util.py", line 9, in <module>
    from azure.storage.blob import BlockBlobService
ImportError: cannot import name BlockBlobService
```

The fix was to uninstall azure-storage-blob 12.0.0 and install azure-storage-blob 2.1.0.

items.title: Release of boto3 1.10.2 breaks snowflake.connector, no workaround in AWS Lambda
items.body:
Please answer these questions before submitting your issue. Thanks!

1. What version of Python are you using (`python --version`)?
3.7

2. What operating system and processor architecture are you using (`python -c 'import platform; print(platform.platform())'`)?
AWS Lambda

AWS released version 1.10.2 of boto3 yesterday, this is the version present in all Lambda execution environments, over which the end user has no control.
https://pypi.org/project/boto3/#history

The boto3 release includes and update to botocore, which includes this commit: 
https://github.com/boto/botocore/commit/6ae424710109b1730cecdb1d3ae27a19a8454a58

The removal of `botocore.vendored.requests` breaks the import of snowflake.connector due to the dependence on botocore.vendored.requests here: https://github.com/snowflakedb/snowflake-connector-python/blob/master/network.py#L21.

This is a a very serious breaking issue, because all new Lambda executions come with a boto3/botocore environment provided by AWS, breaking existing deployed production code without it changing.

Suggested fix: if you need requests.adapters, add an explicit dependency rather than trying to pick it up transitively through botocore.

To reproduce:

```
import snowflake.connector
```

items.title: 1.9.0 is no longer on pypi
items.body: It seems 1.9.0 has been pulled from pypi. This will break any pipeline and build processes that is version locked to 1.9.0 (with an asn1crypto lock to make it work). Please don't pull things from pypi, especially not versions that have been released for a considerable amount of time.

items.title: Current version too big for AWS Lambda - make pyarrow and other non 'core' functionality optionally installed
items.body:
We are using Python 3.7.4 running the 2.0.1 version of the connector
Local environments use MacOS and Production environments use alpine, debian based, and amazon linux based OS environments.

I believe that some of the larger components of this library should be optionally deployed as extras.  Similar to how projects like airflow handle it.

We have an app running a 1.7 version of the connector and the package size was about 80 MB, now with things like pyarrow, the package is close to 380MB and cannot be used with AWS Lambda.

I could not see away to prevent certain dependencies from being deployed with out manually deleting from the venv.

Please advise if this is something that can get some exposure or if there are other workarounds you have to keep the installed package small enough for AWS lambda.

AWS Lambda has package limit of 250MB

items.body:
Please answer these questions before submitting your issue. Thanks!

1. What version of Python are you using (`python --version`)?

2. What operating system and processor architecture are you using (`python -c 'import platform; print(platform.platform())'`)?
`Linux-4.9.184-linuxkit-x86_64-with`

3. What are the component versions in the environment (`pip list`)? 
```
/ # pip list
Package    Version
---------- -------
pip        19.2.3
setuptools 41.2.0
wheel      0.33.6
```

4. What did you do?
If possible, provide a recipe for reproducing the error.
A complete runnable program is good.

1) make this Dockerfile:
```
FROM python:3.7-alpine
RUN apk add --no-cache build-base libffi-dev openssl-dev
RUN pip install snowflake-connector-python
```
2) run `docker build .`

5. What did you expect to see?
I expected snowflake to install!

6. What did you see instead?
```
    ERROR: Command errored out with exit status 1:
     command: /usr/local/bin/python -c 'import sys, setuptools, tokenize; sys.argv[0] = '"'"'/tmp/pip-install-z73b_b7g/pyarrow/setup.py'"'"'; __file__='"'"'/tmp/pip-install-z73b_b7g/pyarrow/setup.py'"'"';f=getattr(tokenize, '"'"'open'"'"', open)(__file__);code=f.read().replace('"'"'\r\n'"'"', '"'"'\n'"'"');f.close();exec(compile(code, __file__, '"'"'exec'"'"'))' egg_info --egg-base pip-egg-info
         cwd: /tmp/pip-install-z73b_b7g/pyarrow/
    Complete output (5 lines):
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
      File "/tmp/pip-install-z73b_b7g/pyarrow/setup.py", line 29, in <module>
        from Cython.Distutils import build_ext as _build_ext
    ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'Cython'
    ----------------------------------------
ERROR: Command errored out with exit status 1: python setup.py egg_info Check the logs for full command output.
```

7. Can you set logging to DEBUG and collect the logs?
We don't get that far.


Looking through the code, I think the fix for this is to only add `pyarrow` to `install_requires` if `isBuildExtEnabled == 'true'`.

items.title: Support other session parameters
items.body:
The JDBC docs note that any session parameter can be included in a connection string: https://docs.snowflake.net/manuals/user-guide/jdbc-configure.html#other-parameters

This would be useful in the Python connector as well. E.g. we try to keep query_tags on as many of our workloads as possible and would would like to make it part of all of our connection params by default.

Note - if this is already possible using the `kwargs` to connect, I wasn't able to get it to work with tagging.

items.title: Using python datetime in `SELECT` statement confusion
items.body:
Please answer these questions before submitting your issue. Thanks!

1. What version of Python are you using (`python --version`)?

`Python 3.6`

2. What operating system and processor architecture are you using (`python -c 'import platform; print(platform.platform())'`)?

`Darwin-18.7.0-x86_64-i386-64bit`

3. What are the component versions in the environment (`pip list`)? 

```
snowflake-connector-python        1.8.4
```

4. What did you do?
If possible, provide a recipe for reproducing the error.
A complete runnable program is good.

```
con = snowflake.connector.connect(
  user='user',
  password='pwd',
  account='account',
  warehouse='wh',
  database='db',
  schema='schema'
)

date = datetime.date.today()

query = """
SELECT *
FROM MY_TABLE
WHERE LAST_UPDATE_DATE={}
LIMIT 100""".format(date)
res = con.cursor().execute(query).fetchall()
```

5. What did you expect to see?

All the data where `LAST_UPDATE_DATE` = datetime.date.today()

6. What did you see instead?

The following error

```
ProgrammingError: 001038 (22023): SQL compilation error:
Can not convert parameter '(2019 - 9) - 7' of type [NUMBER(6,0)] into expected type [DATE]
```

I also tried using 

`WHERE LAST_UPDATE_DATE=("TIMESTAMP_TZ", {})` from googling around but that didn't work. I don't really know what I'm doing...

It seems like all the resources involved `INSERT` but I'm trying to filter on it

7. Can you set logging to DEBUG and collect the logs?

No, I don't have access to the actual machine where the DB is

items.title: execute_stream documentation is out of sync with implementation
items.body:
Please answer these questions before submitting your issue. Thanks!

1. What version of Python are you using (`python --version`)?
3.7

2. What operating system and processor architecture are you using (`python -c 'import platform; print(platform.platform())'`)?
Win10 x64

3. What are the component versions in the environment (`pip list`)? 
n/a

4. What did you do?
`for cur in self.con.execute_stream(f, remove_comments=True, return_cursors=True):`

5. What did you expect to see?
The documentation:
https://docs.snowflake.net/manuals/user-guide/python-connector-api.html#execute_string
Shows the execute_stream taking 2 optional parameters.
Looking at the source it appears there is no implementation for parameter 'return_cursors'.
The documentation should be updated.

6. What did you see instead?
TypeError: execute_stream() got an unexpected keyword argument 'return_cursors'

items.title: Snowflake pyasn1 requirements issue
items.body:
Please answer these questions before submitting your issue. Thanks!

1. What version of Python are you using (`python --version`)?
2.7.16
2. What operating system and processor architecture are you using (`python -c 'import platform; print(platform.platform())'`)?
Ubuntu 16
3. What are the component versions in the environment (`pip list`)? 


The snowflake connection does not work with the following components which are installed as part of the pip install. 
pyasn1==0.4.7 and pyasn1-modules==0.2.6


When attempting to connect I received the following error 
snowflake.connector.errors.OperationalError: 250003: Failed to execute request: Attempted "__iter__" operation on ASN.1 schema object

Instead I had to use pyasn1==0.4.5 and pyasn1-modules==0.2.5 and the connection worked properly.

items.title: Remove botocore.vendored.requests
items.body:
Botocore's vendored `requests` should not be used.

* Botocore itself no longer uses its vendored requests, and only keeps it around for exceptions.
* The vendored requests version is stale and not being updated.
* The vendored requests version is subject to open CVEs and is not being patched.
* A future botocore version will remove vendoring.

References:

* https://github.com/boto/botocore/issues/1703
* https://github.com/boto/botocore/issues/1615
* https://github.com/boto/botocore/issues/1608
* https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2018-20060
* https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2018-18074

items.title: Support for urllib3 1.25 series
items.body:
Please answer these questions before submitting your issue. Thanks!

1. What version of Python are you using (`python --version`)?
`Python 2.7.16 :: Anaconda, Inc.`

2. What operating system and processor architecture are you using (`python -c 'import platform; print(platform.platform())'`)?
`Darwin-18.7.0-x86_64-i386-64bit`

3. What are the component versions in the environment (`pip list`)? 
```
snowflake-connector-python         1.8.7      
snowflake-sqlalchemy               1.1.14  
requests                           2.22.0     

```

4. What did you do?
If possible, provide a recipe for reproducing the error.
A complete runnable program is good.
I installed snowflake-sqlachemy and requests. I expected the install to work, but it appears to have failed because snowflake-connector-python constrains urllib3 version to <1.25 series.


5. What did you expect to see?
Successful install

6. What did you see instead?
`ERROR: snowflake-connector-python 1.8.7 has requirement urllib3<1.25,>=1.21.1; python_version < "3.5", but you'll have urllib3 1.25.3 which is incompatible.`

7. Can you set logging to DEBUG and collect the logs?

```
import logging
import os

for logger_name in ['snowflake.sqlalchemy', 'snowflake.connector', 'botocore']: 
    logger = logging.getLogger(logger_name)
    logger.setLevel(logging.DEBUG)
    ch = logging.StreamHandler()
    ch.setLevel(logging.DEBUG)
    ch.setFormatter(logging.Formatter('%(asctime)s - %(threadName)s %(filename)s:%(lineno)d - %(funcName)s() - %(levelname)s - %(message)s'))
    logger.addHandler(ch)
```

N/A in this case.

This is definitely a minor issue -- urllib3 1.25 is still moderately new and there's not an actual conflict. I was surprised the transitive dependency check didn't solve this (?). Anyway, minor flag in case it's useful/easy for you all to allow the newer urllib3.

items.title: JDBC driver not able to connect to Snowflake. Error code: 390100, Message: Incorrect username or password was specified
items.body:

Also used package option and jar option in .\bin\pyspark --packages .. but no success.
Is it some kind of version issue,any leads?
**Environment details :-**
    windows 10
    python 3.6.6(jupyter notebook)
    spark 2.4.3
    snowflake-jdbc 3.8.1
    spark-snowflake_2.11-2.4.13-spark_2.4

[community.snowflake question](https://community.snowflake.com/s/question/0D50Z00009DoRXlSAN/how-to-solve-py4jjavaerror-an-error-occurred-while-calling-o37load-netsnowflakeclientjdbcsnowflakesqlexception-jdbc-driver-not-able-to-connect-to-snowflake-error-code-390100-message-incorrect-username-or-password-was-specified?t=1559024924205)

import numpy as np

from pyspark.conf import SparkConf

items.title: Binding data in type (dict) is not supported
items.body:
per https://docs.snowflake.net/manuals/user-guide/python-connector-api.html
gives the example:
```
pyformat: .execute("... WHERE my_column = %(name)s", {"name": value})
```

However the (redacted) code:
```
cur.execute('''
        CREATE TEMPORARY TABLE identifier(%(temp_load)s)
        AS
       ...
        ''', { 'temp_load': os.environ['SNOWFLAKE_TEMP_SCHEMA'] + '.temp_load' })
```

gives the error:

items.title: Nones not accepted with qmark parameter style!!
items.body:
Python 3.6.7 on Linux-4.15.0-47-generic-x86_64-with-Ubuntu-18.04-bionic, and 
snowflake-connector-python 1.7.10

I had set the `snowflake.connector.paramstyle = 'qmark'` to circumvent the bug #37 in snowflake-connector-python, and everything worked fine and dandy *until* I noticed that `qmark` parameter style does not support `None`s for input?!!!

```
import snowflake.connector
snowflake.connector.paramstyle = 'qmark'

con = snowflake.connector.connect(...)
con.cursor().execute('USE WAREHOUSE DEMO_WH')
con.cursor().execute('USE demo_db.public')
con.cursor().execute('CREATE TABLE foo(bar text)')
con.cursor().execute('INSERT INTO foo VALUES (?)', [None])
```

and I get the exception `snowflake.connector.errors.ProgrammingError: 252011: None: Python data type [nonetype] cannot be automatically mapped to Snowflake data type. Specify the snowflake data type explicitly.`

The [PEP 249 -- Python Database API Specification v2.0](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0249/) very clearly states that 

> SQL NULL values are represented by the Python `None` singleton on input and output.

This is not fun anymore because I've got a tight schedule in this project and essential bug reports to the Connector (#37 for example) seem to have been closed without correct resolution, with a referral to a "fix" that creates even more problems down the road and I feel I am in general spending more time tracking various "features" in Snowflake and the Connector and the SQLAlchemy dialect than I am writing actual code (including problems with closing the connections upon exception being thrown / program hanging / weird SIGINT rebinding etc).

items.title: Make LOG_MAX_QUERY_LENGTH configurable
items.body:
It would be very helpful for debug and auditing purposes if LOG_MAX_QUERY_LENGTH were configurable at connect time.

1. What version of Python are you using (`python --version`)?
3.6


2. What operating system and processor architecture are you using (`python -c 'import platform; print(platform.platform())'`)?
Multiple

3. What are the component versions in the environment (`pip list`)?
Not relevant for a feature request.

4. What did you do?
If possible, provide a recipe for reproducing the error.
A complete runnable program is good.

I enabled logging per instructions https://docs.snowflake.net/manuals/user-guide/python-connector-example.html#logging

5. What did you expect to see?
The full query text of the queries that were run.

6. What did you see instead?
The first 80 characters of the query, which is a pity because we had the whole query and chose to abbreviate it.

7. Can you set logging to DEBUG and collect the logs?
No, but I can see that the information is truncated at
https://github.com/snowflakedb/snowflake-connector-python/blob/5be6b8c6531aac7c2ca3858be784c5f5f714a0e4/cursor.py#L68

items.title: database/schema in constructor
items.body:
When creating a `SnowflakeConnection`, the `database`/`schema` can be passed in as argument.  Should/does that obsolete the need to explicitly call `use database/schema ...`?

https://docs.snowflake.net/manuals/user-guide/python-connector-example.html#using-the-database-schema-and-warehouse

items.title: connection hangs for 1.6.5 when importing connect from another module
items.body:
I am fairly confident why this is happening (I believe we are seeing a deadlock here) but wanted to get confirmation / detailed explanation from you.

The exact line this is happening on is when calling `pool.join()`:
_ocsp_pyasn1.py_
```
        try:
            for issuer_and_subject in cert_data:
                ocsp_uri = issuer_and_subject['subject'][
                    'ocsp_uri']  # issuer's ocsp uri
                ocsp_subject = issuer_and_subject['subject']
                ocsp_issuer = issuer_and_subject['issuer']
                logger.debug('ocsp_uri: %s', ocsp_uri)
                if ocsp_uri:
                    r = pool.apply_async(
                        self.validate_by_direct_connection_simple,
                        [ocsp_uri, ocsp_issuer, ocsp_subject])
                    results.append(r)
                else:
                    raise OperationalError(
                        msg=(u'NO OCSP URI was found: '
                             u'hostname={0}, subject={1}').format(
                            hostname, ocsp_subject),
                        errno=ER_FAILED_TO_GET_OCSP_URI,
                    )
        finally:
            pool.close()
            pool.join()
```

`Python 2.7.14`

4. What did you do?
_foo.py_
```
from snowflake.connector import connect
conn = connect(user='<>', account='<>', authenticator='externalbrowser')
```

_bar.py_
```
from foo import conn
```

5. What did you expect to see?
a `conn` obj

6. What did you see instead?
A hanging connection

items.title: numpy.bool_ not supported as a binding type
items.body:
When trying to load data from a python tuple, I was receiving the error:
```
None: Failed processing pyformat-parameters; 255001: None: Binding data in type (bool_) is not supported
```

It looks like numpy.bool_ is not a supported binding type. Not sure if this is intentional for some reason.

items.title: ImportError: cannot import name 'DEFAULT_CLIENT_PREFECTH_THREADS'
items.body:
Please answer these questions before submitting your issue. Thanks!

1. What version of Python are you using (`Python 3.6.7 :: Anaconda, Inc.`)?

2. What operating system and processor architecture are you using (`Windows-10-10.0.15063-SP0`)?

3. What are the component versions in the environment (`snowflake-connector-python 1.7.4`)? 

4. What did you do?
a) Ran validate.py script available on the [Snowflake documentation](https://docs.snowflake.net/manuals/user-guide/python-connector-install.html)
b) Got error below

If possible, provide a recipe for reproducing the error.
A complete runnable program is good.

5. What did you expect to see? `Script should output the current version`

6. What did you see instead? 

```
ImportError                               Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-4-08526089813f> in <module>
----> 1 import snowflake.connector

~\AppData\Local\Continuum\anaconda3\lib\site-packages\snowflake\connector\__init__.py in <module>
     19 from .version import (VERSION)
     20 from .compat import (TO_UNICODE)
---> 21 from .connection import SnowflakeConnection
     22 from .cursor import DictCursor
     23 from .errors import (

~\AppData\Local\Continuum\anaconda3\lib\site-packages\snowflake\connector\connection.py in <module>
     22 from .auth_okta import AuthByOkta
     23 from .auth_webbrowser import AuthByWebBrowser
---> 24 from .chunk_downloader import (
     25     SnowflakeChunkDownloader,
     26     DEFAULT_CLIENT_PREFETCH_THREADS,

ImportError: cannot import name 'DEFAULT_CLIENT_PREFETCH_THREADS'
```

7. Can you set logging to DEBUG and collect the logs?

```
import logging
import os

for logger_name in ['snowflake.sqlalchemy', 'snowflake.connector', 'botocore']: 
    logger = logging.getLogger(logger_name)
    logger.setLevel(logging.DEBUG)
    ch = logging.StreamHandler()
    ch.setLevel(logging.DEBUG)
    ch.setFormatter(logging.Formatter('%(asctime)s - %(threadName)s %(filename)s:%(lineno)d - %(funcName)s() - %(levelname)s - %(message)s'))
    logger.addHandler(ch)
```

items.title: No module named 'azure.common'; 'azure' is not a package
items.body:
Since upgrading to v1.7.3 I get the following error when importing snowflake.connector.
No module named 'azure.common'; 'azure' is not a package

I'm running snowflake on Docker (python:3.6-slim-stretch), and install using pip. Reverting back to 1.7.2 resolves the issue, but obviously this isn't great in the long run.

items.title: Okta Authenticator does not support Okta MFA
items.body: I'm unable to use the snowflake python connector when using the Okta url authenticator because my organization has MFA turned on for Okta. Stepping through the auth_okta.py code, when grabbing the one time token in method _step3, the code fails to check the return's status, which is set to 'MFA_REQUIRED'. Judging from https://developer.okta.com/docs/sdk/core/python_api_sdk/api/clients/AuthClient there's an addition flow that needs to be completed when MFA is turned on.

items.title: Discussion: Use of keyring library
items.body:
This is more of a discussion, and not a specific issue, but I thought it would make sense to put it out here.

Let me give you a bit of context so you see where I come from.

At my [company](https://github.com/daltix) we are implementing Airflow as our main scheduler. We just migrated to Snowflake from s3/athena, and we are pretty happy with it.

As part of the migration we need to set up jobs in Airflow that perform a set of ETL scripts that modify our Snowflake datalake.

*"No problem, I can set Airflow up"* I said, unknown to me that the next couple days would be hell.

See, I have set up Airflow multiple times. I spin a machine, build an AMI, spin up an ubuntu 18.04 EC2 instance to test the ami, set up a auth user and test some dags. 

At this moment I am a happy camper, but I just realize that I forgot to add the snowflake dependencies.

So on my builder script I just change 

`pip install apache-airflow[s3,slack]`

to:

`pip install apache-airflow[s3,slack,snowflake]`.

Then I run everything again,  seems to be ok, but surprise!, when I do: 

`from airflow.contrib.hooks.snowflake_hook import SnowflakeHook`

I get the following error:

```
    from keyring.util.escape import escape as escape_for_ini
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'keyring.util.escape'
```

*"Oh boy"* I think, lets  see how we can fix this. I start the research.

It turns out that the keyring package has [an outstanding bug in launchpad](https://bugs.launchpad.net/usd-importer/+bug/1794041). that doesnt help.

Then I see that the `keyring.util.escape` [has been deprecated since 15.0.0](https://github.com/jaraco/keyring/blob/master/CHANGES.rst#1500), if I do `pip freeze` I get that my installed version is `17.0.0`, why is it happening?

Well, it turns out, the keyring package is linked to the [python-cryptography package](https://github.com/pyca/cryptography/issues/3815) that is used on a OS level to do things like for example, allowing ssh into the machine.

A few hours later (i wont explain the details) I managed to fix the issue (I had to update the keyrings.alt package for my environment). And then I started thinking.

**Why the hell does Airflow Snowflake require all this mess with the keyring package**?

Then I find out that the [keyring is required](https://github.com/snowflakedb/snowflake-connector-python/blob/master/setup.py#L50) in the snowflake-connector-python (this one), and it is used as a convenience so you can use your OS keyring to retrieve the passwords. I understand that for a person using the connector on a daily basis to analyze data this is very convenient (so they dont have to type their credentials again and again as a peasant).

But the thing is, not a  single Database connector in python does this! Why does a connection library care about how the user handles their secrets? How is it that somehow this minor convenience has ended up all the way in Apache Airflow dependencies for Snowflake?

I would very much suggest (and let me know if you need help with a PR, since it should be relatively easy to implement) to remove secret management from a DB connector and let other libraries handle that

items.title: Timestamp type converters slowing down fetching data.
items.body:
It seems that fetching results with timestamps is very slow due to the way type conversion is handled in the connector. (I found this after working around the issue in #134, so the slowness described here is unrelated to the other issue).

From what I can understand the timestamps are downloaded as text float values, and later converted using various lamda and local functions using `datetime.datetime`. This is done one by one in a nested loop that goes over each row and each value and applies the lambdas. For large results set this tends to be actually slower than the download.

This issue is mainly to:
1) Report this slowness, so that hopefully some solution can be found.
2) Propose partial mitigations.
3) Document / share the workarounds I've tried so that other people with a similar problem may go straight to the ones that work (without going through the ones that don't).

Proposed solution: 
1) For large result sets with timestamps issue a `logger.warning('timestamp conversion may slow down fetching, if download is faster without timestamp data, try converting timestamp to epoch / string in the query'`
2) Allow controls to disable / control timestamp type conversion during the fetching stage, and just pass on the unix epoch in the results.
3) Batch convert using numpy / pandas e.g. `pd.to_datetime(epoch_seconds, unit='s')`, instead of one by one.

Workarounds that worked:
1) Converting timestamps in the query to epoch_seconds using `date_part(epoch, your_timestamp_column)`. And later (after having the data in an array / dataframe) using `pd.to_datetime(epoch_seconds, unit='s')`.
2) If you only need a timestamp as string and not as datetime object - cast it to string in the query using e.g. `your_timestamp_col::varchar`

Workarounds that don't work:
1) Trying to spread the conversion using multiprocessing. First of all, as in #81, the converter functions are lambdas / local scope functions so aren't pickleable. But even using a package like `pathos` that can pickle those, the overhead over pickling that much data back and forth and the actual slowness of using the converters that act on each individual value make this workaround slower rather faster for my case.
2) Trying other convertors (like numpy's, that are in the converter module)

items.title: Large limit values causing server-side OOM errors.
items.body:
A limit command with large values causes an out of memory error (on server-side - snowflake side) and the query fails (during execution, before any data is returned) even for a reasonable amount of results. 

Below are query-ids for actual queries that can be investigated.

The error reported is` "snowflake.connector.errors.ProgrammingError: 100130 (53200): baeb64b3-b38d-4e13-959a-c76ee79d59be: Out of memory error caused by LIMIT and/or OFFSET clause. Try reducing the number of rows requested."`. 

This happens in very puzzling circumstances. Example: 
1) query (`e07ca7cc-ee06-45a0-a39d-4be23808a463`) succeeds with a limit of 1M.
2) query (`e1eb2308-fd2a-49c6-8cf5-976d3180acc4`) succeeds and downloads results without a limit at all, but with 40M rows.
3) query (`df7154f4-5deb-4045-9af9-89968b34c9a2`) with limit of just 5M, which is a smaller number of results than the full query, fails with the aforementioned error on execution. 

From the wording of the error message this looks like a known issue already, but a limit clause is a very common and useful feature when only a subset of the full results set is needed. 

How is it possible to query for a limited (but large) amount of results?

items.title: Download concurrency control
items.body:
It seems that there is no easy way to set the download concurrency settings for the connector. 

This results in very slow downloads for large result sets (as the default values are quite small).

From what I understand the smaller between `DEFAULT_CLIENT_RESULT_PREFETCH_SLOTS` and `DEFAULT_CLIENT_RESULT_PREFETCH_THREADS` controls the concurrency. 

At runtime those parameters are also received from the query response, but there doesn't seem to be a way to set them. Executing `ALTER SESSION SET CLIENT_PREFETCH_THREADS = 10` has no effect, and `ALTER SESSION SET CLIENT_RESULT_PREFETCH_SLOTS = 10` results in `invalid parameter 'CLIENT_RESULT_PREFETCH_SLOTS'` error.

What this causes is a very slow download, because if some chunk is slow to download or the connection is dropped, it delays the download of all other chunks.

Monkey patching the relevant parts of the code to increase those values at runtime results in much faster download speeds.

The questions are:
1) What is the supported way to increase concurrency? 
2) If there is none yet, will you be willing to accept a PR to the connector that enables a simpler override for those values?

items.title: PUT documentation says source_compression=AUTO, source says auto_detect
items.body:
The [snowflake documentation on the PUT command](https://docs.snowflake.net/manuals/sql-reference/sql/put.html) claims to accept an argument of `SOURCE_COMPRESSION = AUTO`.  This is not the case.  The value the python connector expects is `auto_detect`.  Using `source_compression = auto_detect` in a PUT command, works.  Using `source_compression = AUTO` returns an error.  Somewhere in the cursor object, the request is getting sent to snowflake (`cursor._connection.cmd_query`), where it sets the `ret` return value.
As both the python client, and the java client have always expected `AUTO_DETECT`, something must have changed on snowflake's backend.
https://github.com/snowflakedb/snowflake-connector-python/blame/master/file_transfer_agent.py#L801

items.title: Unclosed resource warnings on PUT query
items.body:
```python
with self.snowflake.cursor() as cursor:
    cursor.execute("PUT file://{} @~/test.csv".format(file))
```

Results in the following warnings:

```
./usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/snowflake/connector/file_transfer_agent.py:153: ResourceWarning: unclosed <socket.socket fd=5, family=AddressFamily.AF_INET, type=2049, proto=6, laddr=('x.x.x.x', 50992), raddr=('y.y.y.y', 443)>
  self._transfer_accelerate_config()
/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/snowflake/connector/file_transfer_agent.py:341: ResourceWarning: unclosed file <_io.BufferedReader name='/tmp/tmpg2_7tg90/test.csv_c.gz'>
  meta[u'real_src_file_name'])
```

Is this a bug in the connector or user error? The cursor and connection are closed properly.

items.title: Python connector triggers MFA push notification
items.body:
I have MFA enabled on my account. Every time I run a Python script that called the Snowflake module, it triggers a Duo Mobile push notification to approve. [This page](https://docs.snowflake.net/manuals/user-guide/security-mfa.html) seems to detail ways to connect using MFA, but doesn't mention Python. My assumption is that once authorized, I should be able to run my script multiple times within a given period without needing to approve every run.

Is there a way around this?

items.title: Implement Heartbeat for python
items.body: Can we get a heartbeat implemented here to eliminate the authentication bug?

items.title: TypeError: not enough arguments for format string
items.body:
Hi, 
I'm using airflow to run some sql scripts. When I try to use query:
select *
from table
where column like '%abc":"def%' 
(% is wildcard for string match)

I got an error: File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/snowflake/connector/cursor.py", line 454, in execute  query = command % processed_params TypeError: not enough arguments for format string

I guess this was caused by some inner config in cursor.py since I could run it on snowflake.

I finally fixed the problem by replacing the first '%' with the exact string. However, that's not a global solution when you do need a wildcard at the beginning of the string.

Could you take a look at this problem and fix it for the future convenience?

Thanks!

items.title: Boto3 list_objects hangs when snowflake.connector loaded
items.body:
Example:

This works:

```
import boto3
client = boto3.Session(profile_name = 'aws_profile').client('s3')
client.list_objects(Bucket = 'bucky-mcbucketface')
```

This doesn't

```
import boto3
import snowflake.connector
client = boto3.Session(profile_name = 'aws_profile').client('s3')
client.list_objects(Bucket = 'bucky-mcbucketface')
```

There is no error or warning message, it just hangs and never completes.

This seems to be caused by a changes to pycryptodome as pinning the installed version to 3.6.2 fixes the issue.
